nodes.name: Patient harm from diagnostic errors in lymph node pathology expert systems
aliases: misdiagnosis harm in lymph node diagnosis
nodes.description: Incorrect disease classification by expert systems such as Pathfinder can lead to inappropriate or delayed treatment, producing morbidity or mortality for patients. (Introduction; Section 7 Results)
nodes.node_rationale: Defines the top-level risk driving all subsequent reasoning paths. (Introduction)

nodes.name: Violation of conditional independence assumptions in multi-hypothesis inference
nodes.description: Inference methods often assume diagnostic features are conditionally independent given a disease (and sometimes its negation); in real lymph-node pathology many features are correlated, breaking this assumption. (Section 3.2; Discussion)
nodes.node_rationale: Identified mechanism that degrades probabilistic reasoning accuracy. (Section 3)

nodes.name: Overcounting of prior probabilities in naive Dempster-Shafer inference
nodes.description: Because D-S masses include prior components, combining many observations multiplies priors, inflating beliefs for some diseases. (Section 3.3 Naive Dempster-Shafer Method)
nodes.node_rationale: Explains why naïve D-S yields poor diagnostic distributions. (Discussion)

nodes.name: Lack of disconfirmatory evidence handling in naive Dempster-Shafer inference
nodes.description: Zero mass assignments leave disease belief unchanged, so evidence that should rule out a hypothesis does not lower its score in naïve D-S. (Section 3.3; Discussion)
nodes.node_rationale: Second key mechanism for D-S degradation. (Discussion)

nodes.name: Washout effect from likelihood renormalization in odds-likelihood method
nodes.description: Renormalising posterior odds across many hypotheses tends to equalise probabilities, producing flatter, less decisive belief distributions. (Section 3.2; Discussion)
nodes.node_rationale: Accounts for expert-noticed under-confidence. (Discussion)

nodes.name: Incomplete representation of feature dependencies in knowledge base
nodes.description: Some morphological features (e.g., necrosis size & distribution) are correlated; representing them separately double-counts evidence unless corrected. (Section 3 Domain)
nodes.node_rationale: Highlights need for knowledge-base restructuring. (Section 3)

nodes.name: Bayesian inference assuming independence on hypotheses improves diagnostic accuracy
nodes.description: Using Bayes’ theorem with independence conditioned only on each disease avoids the extra, often-false assumption about independence given the negation, yielding more peaked and accurate posteriors. (Sections 3.1, 7)
nodes.node_rationale: Core theoretical claim underpinning the preferred inference method. (Section 3.1)

nodes.name: Decision-theoretic evaluation highlights utility-weighted performance differences
nodes.description: Measuring systems with expected utility (micromorts) captures the real harm of misdiagnosis better than raw agreement or expert ratings alone. (Section 4.1; 8 Discussion)
nodes.node_rationale: Justifies adding decision-theoretic tools to evaluation pipelines. (Section 4)

nodes.name: Aggregating dependent features reduces independence violations
nodes.description: Combining correlated observations into composite variables makes the remaining features closer to independent, preserving Bayesian assumptions. (Section 3 Domain; Discussion)
nodes.node_rationale: Provides conceptual basis for clustering design choice. (Section 3)

nodes.name: Adopt simple Bayes inference with maximum expected utility decision rule in diagnostic expert systems
nodes.description: Combining simple Bayesian updating with an MEU choice of diagnosis directly targets patient-utility minimisation. (Sections 3.1; 4.1)
nodes.node_rationale: Design blueprint stemming from the theoretical benefit of Bayes. (Sections 3 & 4)

nodes.name: Use decision-theoretic metrics for system evaluation
nodes.description: Evaluation should employ expected patient-utility rather than only heuristic expert scores to align optimisation with clinical outcomes. (Sections 4; 8)
nodes.node_rationale: Turns utility-based insight into a practical evaluation policy. (Section 4)

nodes.name: Cluster diagnostic features to approximate independence assumptions
nodes.description: Merging correlated features (e.g., necrosis size & distribution) is a systematic way to uphold conditional independence in the knowledge base. (Section 3 Domain)
nodes.node_rationale: Design strategy tied to theoretical insight on aggregation. (Section 3)

nodes.name: Compute posterior probabilities via Equation 3 with priors and feature likelihoods
nodes.description: Implements Bayes’ theorem assuming conditional independence on hypotheses to obtain p(disease | evidence). (Section 3.1)
nodes.node_rationale: Operational step that realises the Bayes+MEU design. (Section 3.1)

nodes.name: Assess diagnostic utilities using micromort-based small-risk value of life
nodes.description: Uses willingness-to-pay and small-risk trade-offs to map outcomes to micromorts, enabling expected-utility calculations. (Section 5 Utility Assessment)
nodes.node_rationale: Implements decision-theoretic evaluation in practice. (Section 5)

nodes.name: Feature clustering implementation in Pathfinder knowledge base
nodes.description: Pathfinder replaces correlated variables (e.g., necrosis size & distribution) with single composite features to remove explicit dependencies. (Section 3 Domain)
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete implementation of the clustering design choice. (Section 3)

nodes.name: Pathfinder 24-case study showing simple Bayes superior
nodes.description: Across 24 referral cases, simple Bayes achieved mean expert rating 8.52/10 and reduced expected harm by ≈ 10 000 micromorts relative to naive D-S. (Section 7 Results; Tables 1–2)
nodes.node_rationale: Empirical confirmation of simple Bayes performance. (Section 7)

nodes.name: Permutation test shows naive D-S inferior (p=0.004)
nodes.description: A Monte-Carlo permutation test found naïve D-S significantly worse than alternatives with p = 0.004. (Section 7 Results)
nodes.node_rationale: Statistical backing for dropping naïve D-S. (Section 7)

nodes.name: Expert rating shows simple Bayes > odds-likelihood (p=0.07)
nodes.description: Wilcoxon rank test on expert scores yielded p = 0.07 favouring simple Bayes over odds-likelihood. (Section 7 Results)
nodes.node_rationale: Empirical evidence differentiating Bayes and OL. (Section 7)

nodes.name: Implement simple Bayes inference with MEU rule in medical expert systems
nodes.description: During system design choose simple Bayesian updating for posterior computation and select the diagnosis that maximises expected patient utility.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Change affects the core inference architecture selected in Section 3.1 Simple Bayes Method.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Validated in a 24-case prototype study with statistical significance (Section 7 Results).
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable step that addresses the identified problems and is empirically supported.

nodes.name: Apply decision-theoretic utility-based evaluation during pre-deployment testing
nodes.description: Before deployment, compute expected micromort loss over representative cases to detect clinically significant errors beyond accuracy metrics.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Executed after model training but before field release as part of test-and-evaluation (Section 4 Evaluation Procedure).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Demonstrated experimentally but not yet routine in industry. (Section 7 & 8).
nodes.node_rationale: Operationalises the decision-theoretic insight to ensure safety prior to deployment.

nodes.name: Cluster correlated diagnostic features during knowledge base construction
nodes.description: Identify strongly correlated observations (e.g., necrosis attributes) and merge them into single composite variables to maintain independence assumptions.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Performed when designing the data schema and knowledge acquisition (Section 3 Domain).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Implemented in Pathfinder prototype; limited external validation. (Section 3).
nodes.node_rationale: Targets dependency-related diagnostic errors through a concrete construction step.

nodes.name: Avoid naive Dempster-Shafer inference in multi-hypothesis domains
nodes.description: Do not employ naïve Dempster-Shafer mass-combination when many mutually exclusive hypotheses and multiple pieces of evidence are present; choose probabilistic alternatives instead.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Inference-algorithm choice is made during model architecture design. (Section 3.3 Naive D-S Method).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Action inferred from comparative study; lacks direct deployment evidence. (Section 7).
nodes.node_rationale: Simple preventive measure to eliminate an empirically inferior method.
